content.description:
Traverse out along the Seal Cove Traverse. Establish a gear belay at the base of the rising crack (before the bolted anchor for Sole Mate). Follow the crack as it ascends up and right. Finish on the last two bolts of Sole Mate.

A third of the way out on the Seal Cove Traverse.
Gear to 2" plus the last two bolts of Sole Mate. Ends at a bolted anchor. Follow climbers trail left across the top of the face to a bolted rappel anchor.

Slab on right side of Seal Cove. Access it by scrambling up and right of the top of Swept Away. Sustained friction on a fairly steep slab. Graded 11a in the guidebook but felt a lot harder than other slabs of the same grade in Squamish. It probably doesn't get much traffic and it seemed a little dirty.

Bolts and some cams for a horizontal

Follows the diagonal crack rightward across the face. Enjoy the undercling, slabby spot, rampy crack up top, and the view out to the water in the direction you're facing! Tree anchor at the top.

Same start as Whanu and Bubble Buddy - a few feet downslope of the trees.
several bolts; SR for the second half

Work past the large scar, then follow a crack up and right, then clip bolts for some slabby face climbing.

Start at a bolted anchor on the far left of the face.
Gear to 2", 3 bolts

More face/slab climbing.  Some runout, but very fun.

Just past the iron ring on the traverse; the first two bolt anchor you come to.
4 quickdraws with optional gear.

climbs.name: Future and a Hope
climbs.fa: Glenn Payan, Jeff Thomson, Shannon Price, Jack Fieldhouse

content.description:
Start on Seal Cove, and traverse out a ways. Then go up a big flake and continue straight up to cracks and bolts.

Starts out on Seal Cove.
3 bolts and standard rack to 2"

climbs.name: Heads I Win, Tails You Lose

content.description:
A long route with some of the finest Seal Cove friction slab climbing, delicate crystal and dyke cruxes as well as some fun crack climbing and a funky traverse.

Climb straight up the slab (crux) and cracks until you can traverse horizontally to the ledge on the left, finish straight up the slab. Variations are possible through the low angle corner or starting on Sea Puppies (both 10a).
content.location:
Rap from the top anchor or do the extended Seal Cove Traverse.

To find the top anchor, walk climbers right on top of the cliff until you can step up the slabs left to reach another trail. Continue a few meters to the first anchor.
content.protection: 12 bolts and take a small rack to .75. At the top and bottom are two-bolt anchors.

content.description:
A long traverse that is a good addition to Barknuckles.

Jeff Thomson did the second half of this pitch in his Reverse Traverse (See www.seatoskyclimbing.ca).
content.location: From the top of Barknuckles or Sole Mate, traverse out to the left and follow that crack all the way to the anchor of Bubble Buddy.

content.description:
Climb up the left hand side of the slab past bolts and a bulge to small cracks where gear can be placed. Belay from the top and rappel of the slings on the tree below.

Left hand side of the slab.  Not necessary to traverse out, and possible to belay from terra firma.
quickdraws and gear to 1.5 inches

This is a flaring chimney through a roof which is on the other side of the cove from the other Seal Cove routes and faces them across the beach. The start is dependent on low tide and is covered by up to 2 m of water at high tide. Don't get stuck belaying at the base while the tide comes in, as on the first attempt. The chimney both flares and leans and is best climbed left side in. Wriggling leads to a palm-and-elbow, knee-and-heel opposed section to the top. A fun and challenging width to practice on. When you hit the beach at Seal Cove, this route is about 40 m north of the other climbs and faces them on a south-facing craglet forming the other side of the cove. Gear to 4". The crack in the back slowly widens so one of 1" to 4" should do it.

No bolts on top. Tie off a tree and salal bushes than scramble down to the east.

climbs.name: The Next Generation
climbs.fa: Jeff Thomson, Will Stanhope, Jeremy Blumel 2005

content.description:
A nice slab route with a difficult section at the 2nd or 3rd bolt, easing off thereafter.  Similar climbing to the other routes here.

This slab route start close to the water (right of Lost Horizon) and trends gently right, crossing Bikini Bottom towards the top.
8 bolts with a few small pieces of gear (to 1")

Traverses the face out to swept away.  Just above the water and feels very thrilling.  Big hardware along the way for the faint of heart.

Start where the ground meets the water!
5 quickdraws (plus optional gear placements)

A great fac/slab climb, with good moves from a belay above the water.

The first belay bolts on the traverse.  Possible to do this from the ground, but better if the belay is on the face.
7 quickdraws

Face climb at the far end of the slab.

All the way out the traverse, which can be as exciting at the climb itself!
7 quickdraws.

Start the same as Bubble Buddy and Bikini Bottom.  Move left early in the pitch.  Crux low.

8 bolts.  Small pro.

The climbing here is good, but the setting is spectacular, though you may have to contend with trains.  The crag itself sits just above Howe Sound.  Hanging belays at high tide are not to be missed.  Seals and otters frequent the cove as well.  Out the traverse, best to belay the second from the top and rap back in from the tree.  Two ropes may be needed otherwise, with the real possibilty of dropping them in the water.
